Lecture 1.Title: Welcome Lecture
Lecture 1.Description: Went over course objectives and learning goals, talked about the role of web systems in our lives, and outlined the course timeline.

Lecture 2.Title: The Basics
Lecture 2.Description: Review of web protocols and html. Talked about the structure of a web-facing application.

Lecture 3.Title: CSS Part 1
Lecture 3.Description: Learned basics of CSS, such as using selectors for styling html.

Lecture 4.Title: CSS Part 2
Lecture 4.Description: More advanced overview of CSS, discussing hierarchy of selectors and stylings like animations

Lecture 5.Title: JavaScript
Lecture 5.Description: Discussed the role of JS in designing impactful applications. Went over syntax and nuances (arrow functions, IIFEs)

Lecture 6.Title: AJAX and JSON
Lecture 6.Description: AJAX was introduced to allow dynamic content without reloading the page, and JSON as a structured data format that integrates easily into Javascript

Lecture 7.Title: APIs
Lecture 7.Description: APIs enable developers to programmatically interact with other applications for seamless integration into one's own application

Lecture 8.Title: Frontend Optimization
Lecture 8.Description: Discussed low-level structure of the DOM, style trees, CSS vs JS runtimes, selector pruning, and backend design patterns

Lecture 9.Title: PHP Functions, Objects, Classes
Lecture 9.Description: Stateless applications often need a backend, a server holding persistent resources. PHP was introduced to solve this issue, and a discussion on PHP development ensued

Lecture 11.Title: Authentication and Authorization
Lecture 11.Description: How to enforce web security for your applications. Various granularities of security were introduced for the purpose of dynamically assigning resource access to persons associated with an organization

Lab 1.Title: Group Portfolio
Lab 1.Description: A website showcasing a group's resumes and backgrounds, united by a common styling and structure

Lab 2.Title: US Constitution Day
Lab 2.Description: Built an application for explaining the historical and current significance of the US Constitution

Lab 3.Title: JavaScript, AJAX, JSON, using APIs
Lab 3.Description: Built a dashboard integrating 2 APIs that utilized dynamic content updates and asynchronous request behavior

Lab 4.Title: AI
Lab 4.Description: Recreated lab 3 using only prompt engineering

Lab 5.Title: Introduction to Bloomberg Terminal
Lab 5.Description: Observed an effective web system in action, capable of immediate data queries and visualizations while integrating with current events

Lab 6.Title: PHP, OOP and Input Handling
Lab 6.Description: Learned how to develop an application backend and design DRY PHP objects
